htmlEmbed:
Has Capitalism Been Replaced by “Technofeudalism”?Sheelah Kolhatkar3/25/2024

The former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis argues in his new book, “Technofeudalism,” that Big Tech has turned us into digital serfs, Sheelah Kolhatkar writes.

visiting dignitary, splitscreenimageleftinset, standard, magazine, , tagsRead

        </script><script type="text/javascript">window.cns = window.cns || {}; window.cns.pageContext = {"channel":"magazine","content":{"copyCount":868,"imageCount":0,"embedCount":2,"ratio":434,"midContentCadence":900},"contentType":"article","experiments":{},"keywords":{"copilotid":["65fc7eefa670d7b76757f60d"],"platform":["verso"],"tags":["the-talk-of-the-town","2024-04-01","magazine","visiting-dignitary"]},"server":"production","slug":"has-capitalism-been-replaced-by-technofeudalism","subChannel":"visiting-dignitary","subSubChannel":"","templateType":"mt_article_two_column"};</script><link rel="preconnect" href="https://ads-static.conde.digital"/><script id="ads-v6" src="https://ads-static.conde.digital/production/cns/builds/the-new-yorker/v6.js" async=""></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"“Nobody’s perfect,” Varoufakis said, laughing. “I’m Greek.”\nVaroufakis, who is tall and bald, with a rakish demeanor, wore boots and a black trenchcoat, like a character from “The Matrix.” In 2015, amid one of the worst financial crises in Greece’s history, he was appointed by the country’s new left-wing government to try to save the financial system and to fend off punishing austerity measures that the country’s creditors had proposed in exchange for a bailout. (During the negotiations, the Financial Times called him “the most irritating man in the room.”) The press referred to Varoufakis as the “rock-star finance minister” and noted his leather jackets and glamorous artist wife, Danae Stratou. “So what that I have a motorcycle,” he said. “I live in Athens—there’s no way you can get around in a car.”\nVaroufakis is still bitter about the way his tenure ended, six months in. He was criticized for appearing in a flashy Paris Match spread at a time when Greeks were suffering economically, and, shortly before the country’s Prime Minister abruptly agreed to the type of bailout that Varoufakis had been resisting, he resigned. (“I shall wear the creditors’ loathing with pride,” he wrote on his blog.)\n“I wanted to do one thing,” he said, hailing a cab to take him to the Guggenheim Museum, a regular New York stop. “Restructure Greece’s debt. If you’re bankrupt, and your bankruptcy gets bigger by getting more credit cards, this is a cycle. I wanted to break this doom loop. And I failed.” He added, “I don’t regret it for a second. But politics stinks.”\nVaroufakis just published his seventeenth book, called “Technofeudalism.” Capitalism, he argues, has been replaced by a new economic system that’s more dangerous than anything Marx could have conjured. The big tech companies—Meta, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet—control our attention and mediate our transactions, he says, turning humans into digital serfs incessantly posting, scrolling, and buying on their platforms. Rather than chasing profits that derive from labor, the tech overlords, whom he calls “cloudalists,” extract “rents.”\nIn the book, Varoufakis refers to Homer, Hesiod, “Mad Men,” F.D.R., Batman, and Thomas Edison to illustrate what has happened since people started staring at smartphones for most of their waking hours. Under feudalism, a landowner would grant fiefs to vassals, who would farm the land and give a portion of the yield to the landowner. Varoufakis writes that Jeff Bezos’s “relationship with the vendors on amazon.com is not too dissimilar.” But the new setup is a bigger threat to representative government than even the old capitalism was.\nThe cab pulled up to the Guggenheim. As Varoufakis paid the fare, he explained that although he’s a critic of technology, he still uses it, especially X. “I’m all day on Twitter,” he said. “I hate it. Was it Stephen Fry, the English writer and actor, who said that it’s like taking all the graffiti from male toilets and posting it online?”\nVaroufakis hadn’t checked the museum’s exhibition schedule but said that he liked surprises. A show called “Going Dark: The Contemporary Figure at the Edge of Visibility” featured images of people wearing hoodies and shrouds, and eerie sculptures of staggering giants bathed in green light. As he peered at the shadowy figures, he said that the only thing that could counter the new tech feudalism was a revolution in which citizens took control of the algorithms and put them under democratic oversight. “A tall order,” he admits in the book.\nHe stared at a large Chris Ofili painting that was almost entirely blue. “When I get seriously depressed, it’s art, music, and ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “I’m a Trekkie, by the way. Absolutely fanatical. I’ve seen every single one.” He especially loves “The Next Generation,” in which Patrick Stewart plays Captain Jean-Luc Picard. “The major reason why I like it is because it’s a post-capitalist, socialist world,” he said. “There’s no money. There’s no profit. And there is the primary directive: We do not interfere with other races. Which is exactly the opposite of the imperialist directive.”\nHe recalled a favorite episode, in which the Enterprise crew thaws several people who were cryogenically frozen: “There is a fantastic dialogue between Captain Picard and a businessman from the nineteen-nineties who demands to see his lawyer because he had a lot of investments on Wall Street. And Picard says, ‘My friend, these were all illusions which are no longer current. We have overcome the need for material possessions.’ ”\nThe ideal system, Varoufakis went on, might be called “anti-technofeudalism.” “With technology working for all of us in a perfectly democratic way, and the removal of systematic exploitation on the basis of who owns what—that’s ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “Whereas I hate ‘Star Wars.’ ‘Star Wars’ is the Middle Ages, with laser guns.” ♦","isBasedOn":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2024/04/01/has-capitalism-been-replaced-by-technofeudalism","articleSection":"visiting dignitary","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Sheelah narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa eunGjt body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="has-dropcap has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading">“I never planned to be a politician. Never. Not in my wildest nightmares,” the economist and former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis said the other day. He was fighting his way toward the exit at Columbia University’s Alfred Lerner Hall, where he’d just spoken at a conference on sustainable development. A man blocked his path: “Five minutes, Professor?” He introduced himself as a U.N. employee. “I’m Italian,” he said.</p><p class="paywall">“Nobody’s perfect,” Varoufakis said, laughing. “I’m Greek.”</p><p class="paywall">Varoufakis, who is tall and bald, with a rakish demeanor, wore boots and a black trenchcoat, like a character from “The Matrix.” In 2015, amid one of the worst financial crises in Greece’s history, he was appointed by the country’s new left-wing government to try to save the financial system and to fend off punishing austerity measures that the country’s creditors had proposed in exchange for a bailout. (During the negotiations, the <em>Financial Times</em> called him “the most irritating man in the room.”) The press referred to Varoufakis as the “rock-star finance minister” and noted his leather jackets and glamorous artist wife, Danae Stratou. “So what that I have a motorcycle,” he said. “I live in Athens—there’s no way you can get around in a car.”</p><div></div><div></div><p class="paywall">Varoufakis is still bitter about the way his tenure ended, six months in. He was criticized for appearing in a flashy <em>Paris Match</em> spread at a time when Greeks were suffering economically, and, shortly before the country’s Prime Minister abruptly agreed to the type of bailout that Varoufakis had been resisting, he resigned. (“I shall wear the creditors’ loathing with pride,” he wrote on his blog.)</p><p class="paywall">“I wanted to do one thing,” he said, hailing a cab to take him to the Guggenheim Museum, a regular New York stop. “Restructure Greece’s debt. If you’re bankrupt, and your bankruptcy gets bigger by getting more credit cards, this is a cycle. I wanted to break this doom loop. And I failed.” He added, “I don’t regret it for a second. But politics stinks.”</p><p class="paywall">Varoufakis just published his seventeenth book, called “Technofeudalism.” Capitalism, he argues, has been replaced by a new economic system that’s more dangerous than anything Marx could have conjured. The big tech companies—Meta, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet—control our attention and mediate our transactions, he says, turning humans into digital serfs incessantly posting, scrolling, and buying on their platforms. Rather than chasing profits that derive from labor, the tech overlords, whom he calls “cloudalists,” extract “rents.”</p><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed"><div Batman, and Thomas Edison to illustrate what has happened since people started staring at smartphones for most of their waking hours. Under feudalism, a landowner would grant fiefs to vassals, who would farm the land and give a portion of the yield to the landowner. Varoufakis writes that Jeff Bezos’s “relationship with the vendors on amazon.com is not too dissimilar.” But the new setup is a bigger threat to representative government than even the old capitalism was.</p><div class="Container-hnJNtl gxMaIG"></div><p class="paywall">The cab pulled up to the Guggenheim. As Varoufakis paid the fare, he explained that although he’s a critic of technology, he still uses it, especially X. “I’m all day on Twitter,” he said. “I hate it. Was it Stephen Fry, the English writer and actor, who said that it’s like taking all the graffiti from male toilets and posting it online?”</p><div><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-iUTMTf jssHut consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--article-mid-content" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--article-mid-content consumer-marketing-unit__slot--in-content"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><p class="paywall">Varoufakis hadn’t checked the museum’s exhibition schedule but said that he liked surprises. A show called “Going Dark: The Contemporary Figure at the Edge of Visibility” featured images of people wearing hoodies and shrouds, and eerie sculptures of staggering giants bathed in green light. As he peered at the shadowy figures, he said that the only thing that could counter the new tech feudalism was a revolution in which citizens took control of the algorithms and put them under democratic oversight. “A tall order,” he admits in the book.</p><p class="paywall">He stared at a large Chris Ofili painting that was almost entirely blue. “When I get seriously depressed, it’s art, music, and ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “I’m a Trekkie, by the way. Absolutely fanatical. I’ve seen every single one.” He especially loves “The Next Generation,” in which Patrick Stewart plays Captain Jean-Luc Picard. “The major reason why I like it is because it’s a post-capitalist, socialist world,” he said. “There’s no money. There’s no profit. And there is the primary directive: We do not interfere with other races. Which is exactly the opposite of the imperialist directive.”</p><p class="paywall">He recalled a favorite episode, in which the Enterprise crew thaws several people who were cryogenically frozen: “There is a fantastic dialogue between Captain Picard and a businessman from the nineteen-nineties who demands to see his lawyer because he had a lot of investments on Wall Street. And Picard says, ‘My friend, these were all illusions which are no longer current. We have overcome the need for material possessions.’ ”</p><p class="paywall">The ideal system, Varoufakis went on, might be called “anti-technofeudalism.” “With technology working for all of us in a perfectly democratic way, and the removal of systematic exploitation on the basis of who owns what—that’s ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “Whereas I hate ‘Star Wars.’ ‘Star Wars’ is the Middle Ages, with laser guns.” ♦</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><aside class="PersistentAsideWrapper-deVGrR daRVRt persistent-aside" One solution? A “Star Trek”-based economy.","head.promo.dek":"The former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis argues in his new book that Big Tech has turned us into digital serfs. One solution? A “Star Trek”-based economy.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"“Nobody’s perfect,” Varoufakis said, laughing. “I’m Greek.”\nVaroufakis, who is tall and bald, with a rakish demeanor, wore boots and a black trenchcoat, like a character from “The Matrix.” In 2015, amid one of the worst financial crises in Greece’s history, he was appointed by the country’s new left-wing government to try to save the financial system and to fend off punishing austerity measures that the country’s creditors had proposed in exchange for a bailout. (During the negotiations, the Financial Times called him “the most irritating man in the room.”) The press referred to Varoufakis as the “rock-star finance minister” and noted his leather jackets and glamorous artist wife, Danae Stratou. “So what that I have a motorcycle,” he said. “I live in Athens—there’s no way you can get around in a car.”\nVaroufakis is still bitter about the way his tenure ended, six months in. He was criticized for appearing in a flashy Paris Match spread at a time when Greeks were suffering economically, and, shortly before the country’s Prime Minister abruptly agreed to the type of bailout that Varoufakis had been resisting, he resigned. (“I shall wear the creditors’ loathing with pride,” he wrote on his blog.)\n“I wanted to do one thing,” he said, hailing a cab to take him to the Guggenheim Museum, a regular New York stop. “Restructure Greece’s debt. If you’re bankrupt, and your bankruptcy gets bigger by getting more credit cards, this is a cycle. I wanted to break this doom loop. And I failed.” He added, “I don’t regret it for a second. But politics stinks.”\nVaroufakis just published his seventeenth book, called “Technofeudalism.” Capitalism, he argues, has been replaced by a new economic system that’s more dangerous than anything Marx could have conjured. The big tech companies—Meta, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet—control our attention and mediate our transactions, he says, turning humans into digital serfs incessantly posting, scrolling, and buying on their platforms. Rather than chasing profits that derive from labor, the tech overlords, whom he calls “cloudalists,” extract “rents.”\nIn the book, Varoufakis refers to Homer, Hesiod, “Mad Men,” F.D.R., Batman, and Thomas Edison to illustrate what has happened since people started staring at smartphones for most of their waking hours. Under feudalism, a landowner would grant fiefs to vassals, who would farm the land and give a portion of the yield to the landowner. Varoufakis writes that Jeff Bezos’s “relationship with the vendors on amazon.com is not too dissimilar.” But the new setup is a bigger threat to representative government than even the old capitalism was.\nThe cab pulled up to the Guggenheim. As Varoufakis paid the fare, he explained that although he’s a critic of technology, he still uses it, especially X. “I’m all day on Twitter,” he said. “I hate it. Was it Stephen Fry, the English writer and actor, who said that it’s like taking all the graffiti from male toilets and posting it online?”\nVaroufakis hadn’t checked the museum’s exhibition schedule but said that he liked surprises. A show called “Going Dark: The Contemporary Figure at the Edge of Visibility” featured images of people wearing hoodies and shrouds, and eerie sculptures of staggering giants bathed in green light. As he peered at the shadowy figures, he said that the only thing that could counter the new tech feudalism was a revolution in which citizens took control of the algorithms and put them under democratic oversight. “A tall order,” he admits in the book.\nHe stared at a large Chris Ofili painting that was almost entirely blue. “When I get seriously depressed, it’s art, music, and ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “I’m a Trekkie, by the way. Absolutely fanatical. I’ve seen every single one.” He especially loves “The Next Generation,” in which Patrick Stewart plays Captain Jean-Luc Picard. “The major reason why I like it is because it’s a post-capitalist, socialist world,” he said. “There’s no money. There’s no profit. And there is the primary directive: We do not interfere with other races. Which is exactly the opposite of the imperialist directive.”\nHe recalled a favorite episode, in which the Enterprise crew thaws several people who were cryogenically frozen: “There is a fantastic dialogue between Captain Picard and a businessman from the nineteen-nineties who demands to see his lawyer because he had a lot of investments on Wall Street. And Picard says, ‘My friend, these were all illusions which are no longer current. We have overcome the need for material possessions.’ ”\nThe ideal system, Varoufakis went on, might be called “anti-technofeudalism.” “With technology working for all of us in a perfectly democratic way, and the removal of systematic exploitation on the basis of who owns what—that’s ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “Whereas I hate ‘Star Wars.’ ‘Star Wars’ is the Middle Ages, with laser guns.” ♦","isBasedOn":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fhas-capitalism-been-replaced-by-technofeudalism","articleSection":"visiting She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in She teaches journalism at Yale, where she also runs the Yale Investigative Reporting Lab. Prior to founding the Lab, she ran the Global Migration Project at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She has written on topics as varied as civil forfeiture, debtors’ prisons, climate-change profiteers, and war-zone private military contractors. In 2024, she won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, for her [investigation into the legal doctrine of felony murder](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F12\u002F18\u002Ffelony-murder-laws), which has sent thousands of Americans to jail for crimes they didn’t commit. She also won the 2012 National Magazine Award for Public Interest for her reporting from Iraq and Afghanistan on labor abuses and human trafficking on U.S. military bases, and has received the Michael Kelly Award, the Overseas Press Club’s Joe and Laurie Dine Award for international human-rights reporting, and the Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism. Her reporting on the high-risk use of young people as confidential informants in the war on drugs received a George Polk Award and the Molly National Journalism Prize. In 2019, she won a National Magazine Award for Public Interest for “[No Refuge](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fwhen-deportation-is-a-death-sentence).”\n\nBefore joining *The New Yorker*, Stillman wrote about America’s wars overseas and the challenges facing soldiers at home for *The Atlantic*, *The Nation*, *The New Republic*, Slate, and the Washington *Post*. She co-taught a seminar at Yale on the Iraq War, and also ran a creative-writing workshop for four years at the Cheshire Correctional Institution, a maximum-security men’s prison in Connecticut. She is a contributor to the best-selling anthology “[All We Can Save: Truth, Courage, and Solutions for the Climate Crisis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0593237064),” and her work is included in “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2012](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231162235\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=8cbf9115-cde8-076f-f61&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2017](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231181590).” She was named a MacArthur Fellow in She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in 2022.","socialMedia":[],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"a-critic-at-large","name":"A Critic at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Critic at Large"}],"hed":"The Roving She teaches journalism at Yale, where she also runs the Yale Investigative Reporting Lab. Prior to founding the Lab, she ran the Global Migration Project at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She has written on topics as varied as civil forfeiture, debtors’ prisons, climate-change profiteers, and war-zone private military contractors. In 2024, she won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, for her [investigation into the legal doctrine of felony murder](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F12\u002F18\u002Ffelony-murder-laws), which has sent thousands of Americans to jail for crimes they didn’t commit. She also won the 2012 National Magazine Award for Public Interest for her reporting from Iraq and Afghanistan on labor abuses and human trafficking on U.S. military bases, and has received the Michael Kelly Award, the Overseas Press Club’s Joe and Laurie Dine Award for international human-rights reporting, and the Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism. Her reporting on the high-risk use of young people as confidential informants in the war on drugs received a George Polk Award and the Molly National Journalism Prize. In 2019, she won a National Magazine Award for Public Interest for “[No Refuge](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fwhen-deportation-is-a-death-sentence).”\n\nBefore joining *The New Yorker*, Stillman wrote about America’s wars overseas and the challenges facing soldiers at home for *The Atlantic*, *The Nation*, *The New Republic*, Slate, and the Washington *Post*. She co-taught a seminar at Yale on the Iraq War, and also ran a creative-writing workshop for four years at the Cheshire Correctional Institution, a maximum-security men’s prison in Connecticut. She is a contributor to the best-selling anthology “[All We Can Save: Truth, Courage, and Solutions for the Climate Crisis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0593237064),” and her work is included in “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2012](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231162235\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=8cbf9115-cde8-076f-f61&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2017](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231181590).” She was named a MacArthur Fellow in She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in She teaches journalism at Yale, where she also runs the Yale Investigative Reporting Lab. Prior to founding the Lab, she ran the Global Migration Project at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She has written on topics as varied as civil forfeiture, debtors’ prisons, climate-change profiteers, and war-zone private military contractors. In 2024, she won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, for her [investigation into the legal doctrine of felony murder](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F12\u002F18\u002Ffelony-murder-laws), which has sent thousands of Americans to jail for crimes they didn’t commit. She also won the 2012 National Magazine Award for Public Interest for her reporting from Iraq and Afghanistan on labor abuses and human trafficking on U.S. military bases, and has received the Michael Kelly Award, the Overseas Press Club’s Joe and Laurie Dine Award for international human-rights reporting, and the Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism. Her reporting on the high-risk use of young people as confidential informants in the war on drugs received a George Polk Award and the Molly National Journalism Prize. In 2019, she won a National Magazine Award for Public Interest for “[No Refuge](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fwhen-deportation-is-a-death-sentence).”\n\nBefore joining *The New Yorker*, Stillman wrote about America’s wars overseas and the challenges facing soldiers at home for *The Atlantic*, *The Nation*, *The New Republic*, Slate, and the Washington *Post*. She co-taught a seminar at Yale on the Iraq War, and also ran a creative-writing workshop for four years at the Cheshire Correctional Institution, a maximum-security men’s prison in Connecticut. She is a contributor to the best-selling anthology “[All We Can Save: Truth, Courage, and Solutions for the Climate Crisis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0593237064),” and her work is included in “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2012](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231162235\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=8cbf9115-cde8-076f-f61&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2017](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231181590).” She was named a MacArthur Fellow in She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in She teaches journalism at Yale, where she also runs the Yale Investigative Reporting Lab. Prior to founding the Lab, she ran the Global Migration Project at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She has written on topics as varied as civil forfeiture, debtors’ prisons, climate-change profiteers, and war-zone private military contractors. In 2024, she won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, for her [investigation into the legal doctrine of felony murder](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F12\u002F18\u002Ffelony-murder-laws), which has sent thousands of Americans to jail for crimes they didn’t commit. She also won the 2012 National Magazine Award for Public Interest for her reporting from Iraq and Afghanistan on labor abuses and human trafficking on U.S. military bases, and has received the Michael Kelly Award, the Overseas Press Club’s Joe and Laurie Dine Award for international human-rights reporting, and the Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism. Her reporting on the high-risk use of young people as confidential informants in the war on drugs received a George Polk Award and the Molly National Journalism Prize. In 2019, she won a National Magazine Award for Public Interest for “[No Refuge](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fwhen-deportation-is-a-death-sentence).”\n\nBefore joining *The New Yorker*, Stillman wrote about America’s wars overseas and the challenges facing soldiers at home for *The Atlantic*, *The Nation*, *The New Republic*, Slate, and the Washington *Post*. She co-taught a seminar at Yale on the Iraq War, and also ran a creative-writing workshop for four years at the Cheshire Correctional Institution, a maximum-security men’s prison in Connecticut. She is a contributor to the best-selling anthology “[All We Can Save: Truth, Courage, and Solutions for the Climate Crisis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0593237064),” and her work is included in “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2012](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231162235\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=8cbf9115-cde8-076f-f61&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2017](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231181590).” She was named a MacArthur Fellow in Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in She teaches journalism at Yale, where she also runs the Yale Investigative Reporting Lab. Prior to founding the Lab, she ran the Global Migration Project at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She has written on topics as varied as civil forfeiture, debtors’ prisons, climate-change profiteers, and war-zone private military contractors. In 2024, she won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, for her [investigation into the legal doctrine of felony murder](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F12\u002F18\u002Ffelony-murder-laws), which has sent thousands of Americans to jail for crimes they didn’t commit. She also won the 2012 National Magazine Award for Public Interest for her reporting from Iraq and Afghanistan on labor abuses and human trafficking on U.S. military bases, and has received the Michael Kelly Award, the Overseas Press Club’s Joe and Laurie Dine Award for international human-rights reporting, and the Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism. Her reporting on the high-risk use of young people as confidential informants in the war on drugs received a George Polk Award and the Molly National Journalism Prize. In 2019, she won a National Magazine Award for Public Interest for “[No Refuge](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fwhen-deportation-is-a-death-sentence).”\n\nBefore joining *The New Yorker*, Stillman wrote about America’s wars overseas and the challenges facing soldiers at home for *The Atlantic*, *The Nation*, *The New Republic*, Slate, and the Washington *Post*. She co-taught a seminar at Yale on the Iraq War, and also ran a creative-writing workshop for four years at the Cheshire Correctional Institution, a maximum-security men’s prison in Connecticut. She is a contributor to the best-selling anthology “[All We Can Save: Truth, Courage, and Solutions for the Climate Crisis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0593237064),” and her work is included in “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2012](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231162235\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=8cbf9115-cde8-076f-f61&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2017](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231181590).” She was named a MacArthur Fellow in She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in She teaches journalism at Yale, where she also runs the Yale Investigative Reporting Lab. Prior to founding the Lab, she ran the Global Migration Project at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She has written on topics as varied as civil forfeiture, debtors’ prisons, climate-change profiteers, and war-zone private military contractors. In 2024, she won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, for her [investigation into the legal doctrine of felony murder](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F12\u002F18\u002Ffelony-murder-laws), which has sent thousands of Americans to jail for crimes they didn’t commit. She also won the 2012 National Magazine Award for Public Interest for her reporting from Iraq and Afghanistan on labor abuses and human trafficking on U.S. military bases, and has received the Michael Kelly Award, the Overseas Press Club’s Joe and Laurie Dine Award for international human-rights reporting, and the Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism. Her reporting on the high-risk use of young people as confidential informants in the war on drugs received a George Polk Award and the Molly National Journalism Prize. In 2019, she won a National Magazine Award for Public Interest for “[No Refuge](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fwhen-deportation-is-a-death-sentence).”\n\nBefore joining *The New Yorker*, Stillman wrote about America’s wars overseas and the challenges facing soldiers at home for *The Atlantic*, *The Nation*, *The New Republic*, Slate, and the Washington *Post*. She co-taught a seminar at Yale on the Iraq War, and also ran a creative-writing workshop for four years at the Cheshire Correctional Institution, a maximum-security men’s prison in Connecticut. She is a contributor to the best-selling anthology “[All We Can Save: Truth, Courage, and Solutions for the Climate Crisis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0593237064),” and her work is included in “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2012](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231162235\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=8cbf9115-cde8-076f-f61&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2017](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231181590).” She was named a MacArthur Fellow in A second volume of her essays for the magazine, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in 2022.","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"59097b77019dfc3494ea36db","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2017\u002F05\u002F03\u002F59097b77019dfc3494ea36da_thurman-judith.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Judith Thurman began contributing to *The New Yorker* in 1987 and became a staff writer in 2000. She writes about books, culture, and fashion. Her story on [Yves Saint Laurent](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fswann-song) was chosen for “The Best American Essays of 2003.” In addition to articles about the great couturiers of the twentieth century ([Chanel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F05\u002F23\u002Fscenes-from-a-marriage-2), [Balenciaga](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2006\u002F07\u002F03\u002Fthe-absolutist), [Schiaparelli](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F27\u002Fmother-of-invention)), and the avant-gardists of this one ([Rei Kawakubo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2005\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fthe-misfit-3), [Isabel Toledo](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F03\u002F10\u002Ftwo-for-one), [Alexander McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fdressed-to-thrill)), Thurman has written about performance art ([Marina Abramović](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2010\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fwalking-through-walls)) and photography ([Diane Arbus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2003\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fexposure-time)). Much of her work focusses on the lives of writers, from [Flaubert](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2002\u002F05\u002F06\u002Fan-unsimple-heart) and [Margaret Fuller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2013\u002F04\u002F01\u002Fan-unfinished-woman) to the graphic memoirist [Alison Bechdel](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2012\u002F04\u002F23\u002Fdrawn-from-life). “[First Impressions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2008\u002F06\u002F23\u002Ffirst-impressions),” her 2008 reportage about the world’s oldest art—the Paleolithic paintings at the Chauvet cave, in southern France—was the inspiration for Werner Herzog’s film “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”\n\nShe is the author of “[Isak Dinesen: The Life of a Storyteller](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312135254\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” which won the 1983 National Book Award for Nonfiction and served as the basis for Sydney Pollack’s movie “Out of Africa,” and “[Secrets of the Flesh: A Life of Colette](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0345371038\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” the winner of the Los Angeles *Times* Book Prize for biography and the Salon Book Award for biography. A collection of her *New Yorker* essays, “[Cleopatra’s Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0312427751\u002F?ots=1&tag=thneyo0f-20),” was published in 2007. She has received the Mary McCarthy Award for lifetime achievement; the Rungstedlund Prize, from the Royal Danish Academy; and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style, from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She is also a chevalier of the French Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. A second volume of her *New Yorker* essays, “[A Left-Handed Woman](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLeft-Handed-Woman-Essays-Judith-Thurman\u002Fdp\u002F0374607168),” was published in She teaches journalism at Yale, where she also runs the Yale Investigative Reporting Lab. Prior to founding the Lab, she ran the Global Migration Project at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She has written on topics as varied as civil forfeiture, debtors’ prisons, climate-change profiteers, and war-zone private military contractors. In 2024, she won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, for her [investigation into the legal doctrine of felony murder](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F12\u002F18\u002Ffelony-murder-laws), which has sent thousands of Americans to jail for crimes they didn’t commit. She also won the 2012 National Magazine Award for Public Interest for her reporting from Iraq and Afghanistan on labor abuses and human trafficking on U.S. military bases, and has received the Michael Kelly Award, the Overseas Press Club’s Joe and Laurie Dine Award for international human-rights reporting, and the Hillman Prize for Magazine Journalism. Her reporting on the high-risk use of young people as confidential informants in the war on drugs received a George Polk Award and the Molly National Journalism Prize. In 2019, she won a National Magazine Award for Public Interest for “[No Refuge](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fwhen-deportation-is-a-death-sentence).”\n\nBefore joining *The New Yorker*, Stillman wrote about America’s wars overseas and the challenges facing soldiers at home for *The Atlantic*, *The Nation*, *The New Republic*, Slate, and the Washington *Post*. She co-taught a seminar at Yale on the Iraq War, and also ran a creative-writing workshop for four years at the Cheshire Correctional Institution, a maximum-security men’s prison in Connecticut. She is a contributor to the best-selling anthology “[All We Can Save: Truth, Courage, and Solutions for the Climate Crisis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0593237064),” and her work is included in “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2012](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231162235\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=8cbf9115-cde8-076f-f61&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[The Best American Magazine Writing 2017](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0231181590).” She was named a MacArthur Fellow in has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading"},"“I never planned to be a politician. Never. Not in my wildest nightmares,” the economist and former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis said the other day. He was fighting his way toward the exit at Columbia University’s Alfred Lerner Hall, where he’d just spoken at a conference on sustainable development. A man blocked his path: “Five minutes, Professor?” He introduced himself as a U.N. employee. “I’m Italian,” he said."]],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"“Nobody’s perfect,” Varoufakis said, laughing. “I’m Greek.”"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Varoufakis, who is tall and bald, with a rakish demeanor, wore boots and a black trenchcoat, like a character from “The Matrix.” In 2015, amid one of the worst financial crises in Greece’s history, he was appointed by the country’s new left-wing government to try to save the financial system and to fend off punishing austerity measures that the country’s creditors had proposed in exchange for a bailout. (During the negotiations, the ",["em","Financial Times"]," called him “the most irritating man in the room.”) The press referred to Varoufakis as the “rock-star finance minister” and noted his leather jackets and glamorous artist wife, Danae Stratou. “So what that I have a motorcycle,” he said. “I live in Athens—there’s no way you can get around in a car.”"],["inline-newsletter",{"newsletterType":"slim-newsletter","newsletters":[]}],["journey-inline-newsletter",{"newsletterType":"slim-newsletter","newsletters":[]}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Varoufakis is still bitter about the way his tenure ended, six months in. He was criticized for appearing in a flashy ",["em","Paris Match"]," spread at a time when Greeks were suffering economically, and, shortly before the country’s Prime Minister abruptly agreed to the type of bailout that Varoufakis had been resisting, he resigned. (“I shall wear the creditors’ loathing with pride,” he wrote on his blog.)"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"“I wanted to do one thing,” he said, hailing a cab to take him to the Guggenheim Museum, a regular New York stop. “Restructure Greece’s debt. If you’re bankrupt, and your bankruptcy gets bigger by getting more credit cards, this is a cycle. I wanted to break this doom loop. And I failed.” He added, “I don’t regret it for a second. But politics stinks.”"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Varoufakis just published his seventeenth book, called “Technofeudalism.” Capitalism, he argues, has been replaced by a new economic system that’s more dangerous than anything Marx could have conjured. The big tech companies—Meta, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet—control our attention and mediate our transactions, he says, turning humans into digital serfs incessantly posting, scrolling, and buying on their platforms. Rather than chasing profits that derive from labor, the tech overlords, whom he calls “cloudalists,” extract “rents.”"],["inline-embed",{"props":{"image":{"id":"65fa21878ac7ce34ace59a39","altText":"Man driving car reads long message on his dashboard screen while a trucker screams and waves at him from the Cartoon"}]}},"level":"block","ref":"65fa21878ac7ce34ace59a39","type":"cartoon"}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"In the book, Varoufakis refers to Homer, Hesiod, “Mad Men,” F.D.R., Batman, and Thomas Edison to illustrate what has happened since people started staring at smartphones for most of their waking hours. Under feudalism, a landowner would grant fiefs to vassals, who would farm the land and give a portion of the yield to the landowner. Varoufakis writes that Jeff Bezos’s “relationship with the vendors on amazon.com is not too dissimilar.” But the new setup is a bigger threat to representative government than even the old capitalism was."],["inline-embed",{"type":"cneinterlude","props":{"brand":"newyorker","embeddedVideos":[],"hasExcludedEmbed":false,"playerBase":"https:\u002F\u002Fplayer.cnevids.com","isRightRail":false,"relatedVideo":{"showRelatedVideo":false,"brand":"newyorker","related":null,"pageSize":12}}}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"The cab pulled up to the Guggenheim. As Varoufakis paid the fare, he explained that although he’s a critic of technology, he still uses it, especially X. “I’m all day on Twitter,” he said. “I hate it. Was it Stephen Fry, the English writer and actor, who said that it’s like taking all the graffiti from male toilets and posting it online?”"],["cm-unit"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Varoufakis hadn’t checked the museum’s exhibition schedule but said that he liked surprises. A show called “Going Dark: The Contemporary Figure at the Edge of Visibility” featured images of people wearing hoodies and shrouds, and eerie sculptures of staggering giants bathed in green light. As he peered at the shadowy figures, he said that the only thing that could counter the new tech feudalism was a revolution in which citizens took control of the algorithms and put them under democratic oversight. “A tall order,” he admits in the book."],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"He stared at a large Chris Ofili painting that was almost entirely blue. “When I get seriously depressed, it’s art, music, and ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “I’m a Trekkie, by the way. Absolutely fanatical. I’ve seen every single one.” He especially loves “The Next Generation,” in which Patrick Stewart plays Captain Jean-Luc Picard. “The major reason why I like it is because it’s a post-capitalist, socialist world,” he said. “There’s no money. There’s no profit. And there is the primary directive: We do not interfere with other races. Which is exactly the opposite of the imperialist directive.”"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"He recalled a favorite episode, in which the Enterprise crew thaws several people who were cryogenically frozen: “There is a fantastic dialogue between Captain Picard and a businessman from the nineteen-nineties who demands to see his lawyer because he had a lot of investments on Wall Street. And Picard says, ‘My friend, these were all illusions which are no longer current. We have overcome the need for material possessions.’ ”"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"The ideal system, Varoufakis went on, might be called “anti-technofeudalism.” “With technology working for all of us in a perfectly democratic way, and the removal of systematic exploitation on the basis of who owns what—that’s ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “Whereas I hate ‘Star Wars.’ ‘Star Wars’ is the Middle Ages, with laser guns.” ♦"]],"pageStructure":[["inline-embed",138,"callout"],["p",7],["p",128],["p",68],["p",65],["p",73],["inline-embed",0,"cartoon"],["p",88],["inline-embed",0,"cneinterlude"],["p",62],["cm-unit",0],["p",89],["p",97],["p",69],["p",53]],"hasAffiliateLinks":false,"affiliateLinksCount":0,"isCommerceContent":false,"contributorSpotLightProps":{"header":{"name":"Sheelah Kolhatkar","title":"Sheelah Kolhatkar is a staff writer at *The New Yorker*, where she writes about Wall Street, Silicon Valley, economics, and politics. readabilityObject.title: Has Capitalism Been Replaced by “Technofeudalism”?
readabilityObject.content:
“I never planned to be a politician. Never. Not in my wildest nightmares,” the economist and former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis said the other day. He was fighting his way toward the exit at Columbia University’s Alfred Lerner Hall, where he’d just spoken at a conference on sustainable development. A man blocked his path: “Five minutes, Professor?” He introduced himself as a U.N. employee. “I’m Italian,” he said.

“Nobody’s perfect,” Varoufakis said, laughing. “I’m Greek.”

Varoufakis, who is tall and bald, with a rakish demeanor, wore boots and a black trenchcoat, like a character from “The Matrix.” In 2015, amid one of the worst financial crises in Greece’s history, he was appointed by the country’s new left-wing government to try to save the financial system and to fend off punishing austerity measures that the country’s creditors had proposed in exchange for a bailout. (During the negotiations, the Financial Times called him “the most irritating man in the room.”) The press referred to Varoufakis as the “rock-star finance minister” and noted his leather jackets and glamorous artist wife, Danae Stratou. “So what that I have a motorcycle,” he said. “I live in Athens—there’s no way you can get around in a car.”

Varoufakis is still bitter about the way his tenure ended, six months in. He was criticized for appearing in a flashy Paris Match spread at a time when Greeks were suffering economically, and, shortly before the country’s Prime Minister abruptly agreed to the type of bailout that Varoufakis had been resisting, he resigned. (“I shall wear the creditors’ loathing with pride,” he wrote on his blog.)

“I wanted to do one thing,” he said, hailing a cab to take him to the Guggenheim Museum, a regular New York stop. “Restructure Greece’s debt. If you’re bankrupt, and your bankruptcy gets bigger by getting more credit cards, this is a cycle. I wanted to break this doom loop. And I failed.” He added, “I don’t regret it for a second. But politics stinks.”

Varoufakis just published his seventeenth book, called “Technofeudalism.” Capitalism, he argues, has been replaced by a new economic system that’s more dangerous than anything Marx could have conjured. The big tech companies—Meta, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet—control our attention and mediate our transactions, he says, turning humans into digital serfs incessantly posting, scrolling, and buying on their platforms. Rather than chasing profits that derive from labor, the tech overlords, whom he calls “cloudalists,” extract “rents.”

In the book, Varoufakis refers to Homer, Hesiod, “Mad Men,” F.D.R., Batman, and Thomas Edison to illustrate what has happened since people started staring at smartphones for most of their waking hours. Under feudalism, a landowner would grant fiefs to vassals, who would farm the land and give a portion of the yield to the landowner. Varoufakis writes that Jeff Bezos’s “relationship with the vendors on amazon.com is not too dissimilar.” But the new setup is a bigger threat to representative government than even the old capitalism was.

The cab pulled up to the Guggenheim. As Varoufakis paid the fare, he explained that although he’s a critic of technology, he still uses it, especially X. “I’m all day on Twitter,” he said. “I hate it. Was it Stephen Fry, the English writer and actor, who said that it’s like taking all the graffiti from male toilets and posting it online?”

Varoufakis hadn’t checked the museum’s exhibition schedule but said that he liked surprises. A show called “Going Dark: The Contemporary Figure at the Edge of Visibility” featured images of people wearing hoodies and shrouds, and eerie sculptures of staggering giants bathed in green light. As he peered at the shadowy figures, he said that the only thing that could counter the new tech feudalism was a revolution in which citizens took control of the algorithms and put them under democratic oversight. “A tall order,” he admits in the book.

He stared at a large Chris Ofili painting that was almost entirely blue. “When I get seriously depressed, it’s art, music, and ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “I’m a Trekkie, by the way. Absolutely fanatical. I’ve seen every single one.” He especially loves “The Next Generation,” in which Patrick Stewart plays Captain Jean-Luc Picard. “The major reason why I like it is because it’s a post-capitalist, socialist world,” he said. “There’s no money. There’s no profit. And there is the primary directive: We do not interfere with other races. Which is exactly the opposite of the imperialist directive.”

He recalled a favorite episode, in which the Enterprise crew thaws several people who were cryogenically frozen: “There is a fantastic dialogue between Captain Picard and a businessman from the nineteen-nineties who demands to see his lawyer because he had a lot of investments on Wall Street. And Picard says, ‘My friend, these were all illusions which are no longer current. We have overcome the need for material possessions.’ ”

The ideal system, Varoufakis went on, might be called “anti-technofeudalism.” “With technology working for all of us in a perfectly democratic way, and the removal of systematic exploitation on the basis of who owns what—that’s ‘Star Trek,’ ” he said. “Whereas I hate ‘Star Wars.’ ‘Star Wars’ is the Middle Ages, with laser guns.” ♦
